codeListValue="mapDigital">mapDigital</gmd:CI_PresentationFormCode>                </gmd:presentationForm>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>The Arkansas Secretary of State contracted the University of Arkansas at Little Rock, GIS Applications Laboratory (UALRGIS) to use modern geographic information technology and improved base maps to create a current and spatially accurate statewide depiction of school district boundaries in the State of Arkansas. The Arkansas Geographic Information Office merged annexed and consolidated districts. UALRGIS followed a work plan for the project that was established by the Arkansas Geographic Information Office (AGIO) for the Secretary of State. The school district boundary editing rules were as follows: 1. Legal descriptions take precedent. 2. If no legal description was provided the visual evidence presented on the digital ortho quarter quadrangle (DOQQ) was followed. 3. Section lines, county boundaries, city boundaries and / or roads have only be used as supporting visual evidence viewed on the DOQQ.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>To provide the Arkansas Department of Education with a geographic information system geospatial dataset depicting spatially accurate school district boundaries in a standardized manner. Note: The legal description of the school district boundaries was not modified; only the geometries within the geospatial dataset.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose>          <gmd:credit>             <gco:CharacterString>Arkansas Secretary of State and the University of Arkansas at Little Rock GIS Applications Laboratory</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:credit>          <gmd:status>             <gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode"                                  codeListValue="completed">completed</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>          </gmd:status>          <gmd:pointOfContact>             <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                <gmd:individualName>                   <gco:CharacterString>Phyllis Smith</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:individualName>                <gmd:organisationName>                   <gco:CharacterString>UALR GIS</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:organisationName>                <gmd:positionName>                   <gco:CharacterString>Laboratory Director</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:positionName>                <gmd:contactInfo>                   <gmd:CI_Contact>                      <gmd:phone>                         <gmd:CI_Telephone>                            <gmd:voice>                               <gco:CharacterString>1(501) 569-8534</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:voice>                            <gmd:facsimile>                               <gco:CharacterString>1(501) 569-8538</gco:CharacterString>                            </gmd:facsimile>                         </gmd:CI_Telephone>                      </gmd:phone>                      <gmd:address>                         <gmd:CI_Address>                            <gmd:deliveryPoint>                               <gco:CharacterString>2801 S. </gmd:DQ_CompletenessOmission>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:report>             <gmd:DQ_ConceptualConsistency>                <gmd:measureDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>All school districts received a map of their district. If no contact was made to the secretary of State before the dead line, the most accurate district lines would be approved by default. We worked with the school districts and resolved conflicts with those school districts that responded to the Secretary of State. Hard copy maps prepared with TIGER 2000 school district boundaries, Arkansas Department of Highway and Transportation section lines, and 2000 digital ortho photography were provided to each school district superintendent. Superintendents were asked to denote changes and supply edits back to the Secretary of State. Furthermore, the superintendents would "sign off" on the map if it properly reflected the school district in question. Districts that failed to return edits or a signed copy of the map provided (by the deadline) were deemed correct. UALRGIS and Arkansas Secretary of State worked with school district superintendents to resolve boundary disputes. Once approved, the spatial geometries of each school district were aligned using the legal description, 2000 digital orthos, and section lines if needed.</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:measureDescription>                <gmd:result gco:nilReason="unknown"/>             </gmd:DQ_ConceptualConsistency>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:report>             <gmd:DQ_QuantitativeAttributeAccuracy>                <gmd:nameOfMeasure>                   <gco:CharacterString>Quantitative Attribute Accuracy Assessment</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:nameOfMeasure>                <gmd:measureDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>Attributes have been scrubbed using various database and geospatial techniques</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:measureDescription>                <gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                   <gco:CharacterString>Attributes have been reviewed by the Arkansas Department of Education utilizing the 05-06 Arkansas Education Directory</gco:CharacterString>                </gmd:evaluationMethodDescription>                <gmd:result>                   <gmd:DQ_QuantitativeResult>                      <gmd:valueUnit>                         <gml:BaseUnit gml:id="d3437e243">                            <gml:identifier codeSpace="local">meters</gml:identifier>                            <gml:unitsSystem xlink:href="http://www.bipm.org/en/si/"/>                         </gml:BaseUnit>                      </gmd:valueUnit>                      <gmd:value>                         <gco:Record>3</gco:Record>                      </gmd:value>                   </gmd:DQ_QuantitativeResult>                </gmd:result>             </gmd:DQ_QuantitativeAttributeAccuracy>          </gmd:report>          <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>UALRGIS followed a work plan for the project that was established by the Arkansas Geographic Information Office (AGIO) for the Secretary of State. The school district boundary editing rules were as follows: 1. Legal descriptions take precedent. 2. If no legal description was provided the visual evidence presented on the digital ortho quarter quadrangle (DOQQ) was followed. 3. Section lines, county boundaries, city boundaries and / or roads have only be used as supporting visual evidence viewed on the DOQQ. All school districts received a map of their district. If no contact was made to the secretary of State before the dead line, the most accurate district lines would be approved by default. We worked with the school districts and resolved conflicts with those school districts that responded to the Secretary of State. Hard copy maps prepared with TIGER 2000 school district boundaries, Arkansas Department of Highway and Transportation section lines, and 2000 digital ortho photography were provided to each school district superintendent. Superintendents were asked to denote changes and supply edits back to the Secretary of State. Furthermore, the superintendents would "sign off" on the map if it properly reflected the school district in question. Districts that failed to return edits or a signed copy of the map provided (by the deadline) were deemed correct. UALRGIS and Arkansas Secretary of State worked with school district superintendents to resolve boundary disputes. Once approved, the spatial geometries of each school district were aligned using the legal description, 2000 digital orthos, and section lines if needed. Topology was created and validated by the Arkansas Geographic Information Office. Precision for the geodatabase was 1000 and the cluster tolerance was set at .005</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>2005-09-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:processor>                         <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
